content.description: Climb the low angle dihedral that trends up and left, and then head straight up a featured face.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a chain anchor. The first bolt is up there a ways so some gear may be desired before reaching it.
content.location: Furthest left route at the Egg Wall. Look for a leftward trending low angle dihedral.

content.description: Climb Scrambled until about mid-height, then follow the bolts that head out left.
content.protection: Bolts, gear to 2.5 inches, independent chain anchor. I believe the only gear I placed to supplement the bolts was a #3 Camalot.
content.location: Located towards the right side of the Egg Wall, shares the beginning and first half of Scrambled.

content.description: Head up the right side of the Egg Wall, mostly a slab climb with a couple of small roof/overlap features.
content.protection: 9-10 bolts to an independent chain anchor.
content.location: Right side of Egg Wall. Start is just a bit right of the flat staging area.

content.description: A fun start leads past a couple of bolts to some mellow ground mid route where some gear can be placed. Up higher, the route gets a bit steeper where more bolts are found before reaching the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts, supplemented by standard rack. Independent chain anchor.
content.location: The furthest route to the right at the Egg Wall, above the boulders and just right of the obvious dihedral that is Mahogany Corner. The first two bolts are visible from the ground.

content.description: Climb through a couple of overlaps in the corner, placing gear and clipping one bolt along the way, before arriving at the large tree below the nice looking dihedral. The final 10 feet or so makes this climb worth doing! A bit of lichen at the bottom made the initial friction moves a bit dicey with limited protection so use caution getting off the ground.
content.protection: Standard rack, 1 bolt mid route.  Make sure to bring a couple pieces equivalent to BD 0.3 or Blue Metolius for the finger crack in the final dihedral. Chain anchor.
content.location: On the far right side of the Egg Wall above the boulders, look for an obvious dihedral with several overlaps and good-sized tree 3/4 of the way up.

content.description: This route shares the first 4 bolts with Hard Boiled before cutting left and heading up to the obvious roof. Pull straight over the roof with bolts offering protection. Can use gear to supplement bolts before reaching the roof, although any runout between bolts is on pretty mellow terrain.
content.protection: Bolts leading to independent chain anchor. I used one Blue Mastercam to supplement the bolts leading up to the overhang.
content.location: Look for the obvious roof towards the left side of the Egg Wall. This is the 2nd route from the left, sharing the first 4 bolts with Hard Boiled.

climbs.name: Hard Poached
climbs.fa: unknown  FRA 8-16-19 Jim Pace and Bob Bechaud

content.description: We suspect that this is another Duane Ackerman route but can´t find any record.  Adding it to MP since it´s a fun route and is not in Bingham's guidebook..  Bolt protected below and above the trad. protected "white step". Crux is finding a key hold to pull on/over first small roof, then finding another key hold to move up.  May want to protect second move with a #3 in the horizontal.
content.protection: A few small-medium cams or nuts for the white step section. Optional #3 for crux moves. About 5 bolts below the step and 5 above.  Chain anchors.
content.location: Right of Eggstra Special about 30 feet find line of bolts leading to an obvious step on white rock.

content.description: Climb the slab below the obvious roof, following the line of bolts upward and trending right.
content.protection: 9 bolts to an independent chain anchor.
content.location: Look for the obvious roof on the left side of the Egg Wall. This route begins on the slab below this feature.

content.description: Climb the mellow slab (bolts and gear) before reaching a crack feature and placing gear for the last 30 feet or so of the route.A good mix of gear and bolts on this route.
content.protection: Roughly 5 bolts, gear to 2 inches, independent chain anchor.
content.location: Roughly the center of the Egg Wall. The climb heads up between the two bushes. See topo photo.

climbs.name: Cracked Chorizo
climbs.fa: unknown, FRA 8/17/19 Bob Bechaud & Jim Pace

content.description: An alternative start to Scrambled with Chorizo that offers some easy trad. climbing.  This route is not in Bingham's guidebook.
content.protection: Small/medium cams for cracks, sling for tree, 6 bolts above.
content.location: Follow cracks below left facing corner just to the left of Scrambled.  Climb cracks past tree, then step left on to the bolted Chorizo line to chain anchors.

content.description: A fun route that offers well-protected friction slab climbing. Few actual hand and footholds until near the top of the route, but the mellow angle and adequate rock texture provide plenty of friction.
content.location: Look for the bolted slab roughly 20 feet right of Scrambled.
